On 8/4/10 6:12 AM, Nicolas Giraud wrote:
>
>
> Hi,
>
> I will be using the full frontier report (e.g. queried by the JMX call
> /frontierReport("all")/) to extract some high-level monitoring
> information for our crawl managers,  initially simply extracting the N
> biggest queues from the frontier. I would like a short explanation on
> the semantics of the fields present in this report :
>
> queue
> currentSize
> totalEnqueues
> sessionBalance
> lastCost (averageCost)
> lastDequeueTime
> wakeTime
> totalSpend/totalBudget
> errorCount
> lastPeekUri
> lastQueued
>
> Most of the fields have rather understandable names, but I'd just like
> to make sure I do understand the exact semantics, the unit in which
> values are expressed etc. I was unable to find this information in the
> user guide or by searching online.


Here's a quick rundown:

queue: the string name of the distinct queue within the frontier (also 
sometimes referred to as 'class key')

currentSize: number of URIs currently in the queue

totalEnqueues: count of total times a URI has been enqueued to this 
queue; a measure of the total number of URI instances ever put on this 
queue. This can be a larger number than the unique URIs, as some URIs 
(most notably DNS/robots when refetched, but possibly other things 
force-requeued under advanced usage) may be enqueued more than once

sessionBalance: when using the 'budget/rotation' functionality (a 
non-zero URI cost policy), this is the running 'balance' of a queue 
during its current 'active' session. This balance declines; when it hits 
zero, another queue (if any are waiting 'inactive') gets a chance to 
enter active crawling (as fast as politeness allows).

lastCost (averageCost): the 'cost' of the last URI charged against the 
queue's budgets, and average of all such URIs. If using a cost policy 
that makes some URIs more costly than others, this may indicate the 
queue has reached more-costly URIs. (Such larger-cost URIs will be 
inserted later in the queue, accelerate the depletion of the session 
balance, and accelerate progress towards the total queue budget, which 
could send the queue into 'retirement'. Thus higher-cost URIs mean a 
queue over time gets less of the crawler's cycles.)

lastDequeueTime: timestamp of when the last URI came off this queue for 
processing. May give an indication of how long a queue has been 
empty/inactive.

wakeTime: if the queue is in any sort of politeness- or 
connect-problem-'snooze' delay, this indicates when it will again be 
eligible to offer URIs to waiting threads. (When it wakes, it gets in 
line -- so actual wait before next URI is tried may be longer depending 
on the balance of threads and other active queues.)

totalSpend/totalBudget: The total of all URI costs charged against this 
queue, and the totalBudget above which the queue will be retired (made 
permanently inactive unless its totalBudget is raised).

errorCount: the number of URIs from this queue that reached 'finished' 
status with an error code (non-retryable errors, or exhausted retries, 
or other errors). When nonzero and rising there may be special problems 
with the site(s) related to this queue.

lastPeekUri: the last URI peeked/dequeued from the head of this queue

lastEnqueue: the last URI enqueued to anywhere in this queue

Hope this helps!

- Gordon @ IA
